claim: If you put on one ring, a ring will be on your finger.

supporting.text: By definition, placing a ring on a finger means the ring is now located on that finger.

attacks.text: By definition, placing a ring on a finger means the ring is now located on that finger.
The ring may slip off immediately after being placed, due to improper fit or movement.
Properly fitted rings are unlikely to slip off under normal conditions.
The act of 'putting on' does not guarantee the ring stays on; it could be removed intentionally right after.
The claim specifies the state after 'putting on,' not the persistence of the state.

supporting.text: The physical act of putting a ring on a finger ensures direct contact between the ring and the finger.

attacks.text: The physical act of putting a ring on a finger ensures direct contact between the ring and the finger.
If the ring is too large, it may not stay on the finger despite being put on.
Most rings are designed to fit fingers securely, making slippage rare.
If the finger is missing or amputated, putting on a ring does not result in a ring on the finger.
The claim implicitly assumes the presence of a finger, making this edge case irrelevant in normal contexts.

supporting.text: A ring is designed to encircle a finger, so wearing one inherently means it is on the finger.

attacks.text: A ring is designed to encircle a finger, so wearing one inherently means it is on the finger.
A ring can be worn on body parts other than fingers, such as toes or ears, so wearing one does not necessarily mean it is on the finger.
Common usage of the term 'ring' implies finger rings unless specified otherwise, making the general assumption valid.
A ring might not fit properly or could be worn incorrectly, meaning it is not securely on the finger even if placed there.
Properly designed rings are made to fit standard finger sizes, reducing the likelihood of incorrect placement.

supporting.text: Common language usage confirms that 'putting on a ring' equates to the ring being on the finger.

attacks.text: Common language usage confirms that 'putting on a ring' equates to the ring being on the finger.
In some contexts, 'putting on a ring' could refer to placing it on a display stand or another object, not necessarily a finger.
Technical or legal definitions might distinguish between 'putting on' and 'wearing,' where the latter implies the ring is on the finger.
Common language overwhelmingly associates 'putting on a ring' with wearing it on a finger, making exceptions negligible.

supporting.text: The mechanics of wearing jewelry support the claim, as rings cannot be worn without being on a finger.

attacks.text: The mechanics of wearing jewelry support the claim, as rings cannot be worn without being on a finger.
Rings can be worn on other body parts like toes or ears, not just fingers.
The claim specifies 'a ring will be on your finger,' which implies the default assumption is finger placement unless stated otherwise.
Some rings are designed as pendants or brooches and are not meant to be worn on fingers at all.
Such rings are exceptions and not the common understanding of what 'putting on a ring' entails.

supporting.text: Visual and tactile confirmation aligns with the claim, as the presence of a ring on a finger is observable.

attacks.text: Visual and tactile confirmation aligns with the claim, as the presence of a ring on a finger is observable.
The ring might be placed on a non-finger body part (e.g., toe, necklace), violating the claim's specificity.
The ring could be too large or improperly fitted, causing it to fall off immediately after being put on.
Visual or tactile confirmation could be hallucinated or misinterpreted (e.g., in dreams or virtual reality).
Standard ring-wearing conventions overwhelmingly assume placement on fingers unless specified otherwise.
Illusions or misinterpretations of ring placement are statistically negligible in real-world scenarios.
